[Vatican City]

**Vatican City** ,^[\[f\]](#cite_note-19)^ officially the **Vatican City State** ([Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"): *Stato della Città del Vaticano* ;^[\[g\]](#cite_note-22)^ [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Status Civitatis Vaticanae* ),^[\[h\]](#cite_note-23)^^[\[i\]](#cite_note-24)^ is a [landlocked](/wiki/Landlocked_country "Landlocked country") [sovereign country](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state"),^[\[16\]](#cite_note-25)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-26)^ [city-state](/wiki/City-state "City-state"), [microstate](/wiki/Microstate "Microstate"), and [enclave](/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave "Enclave and exclave") surrounded by, and historically a part of, [Rome, Italy](/wiki/Rome "Rome").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-Britannica-27)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-28)^ It became independent from Italy in 1929 with the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty"), and is a distinct [territory](/wiki/Territory "Territory") under "full ownership, exclusive dominion, and sovereign authority and jurisdiction" of the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), which is itself a [sovereign entity under international law](/wiki/Legal_status_of_the_Holy_See "Legal status of the Holy See"), maintaining the [city-state's temporal power](/wiki/Temporal_power_of_the_Holy_See "Temporal power of the Holy See"), governance, diplomatic, and spiritual independence. The Vatican is also a [metonym](/wiki/Metonym "Metonym") for the [pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope"), the Holy See, and the [Roman Curia](/wiki/Roman_Curia "Roman Curia").^[\[j\]](#cite_note-29)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-lateran-30)^{#cite_ref-lateran_30-0}

With an area of 49 hectares (121 acres)^[\[c\]](#cite_note-area-15)^ and a population of about 764^[\[13\]](#cite_note-population-16)^ (as of 2023), it is the [smallest sovereign state in the world both by area](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and dependencies by area") and [by population](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population "List of countries and dependencies by population").^[\[21\]](#cite_note-31)^ It is also the [second-least populated capital](/wiki/List_of_national_capitals_by_population "List of national capitals by population") in the world. As governed by the Holy See, Vatican City State is an [ecclesiastical](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_jurisdiction "Ecclesiastical jurisdiction") or [sacerdotal](/wiki/Sacerdotal_state "Sacerdotal state")-[monarchical](/wiki/Monarchy "Monarchy") state ruled by the Pope, who is the [bishop of Rome](/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome "Bishop of Rome") and head of the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church").^[\[6\]](#cite_note-factbook-7)^^[\[22\]](#cite_note-pages-32)^ The highest state functionaries are all [Catholic clergy](/wiki/Holy_orders_in_the_Catholic_Church "Holy orders in the Catholic Church") of various origins. After the [Avignon Papacy](/wiki/Avignon_Papacy "Avignon Papacy") (1309--1377) the popes have mainly resided at the [Apostolic Palace](/wiki/Apostolic_Palace "Apostolic Palace") within what is now Vatican City, although at times residing instead in the [Quirinal Palace](/wiki/Quirinal_Palace "Quirinal Palace") in Rome or elsewhere.{#cite_ref-pages_32-0}

The Holy See dates back to early Christianity and is the principal [episcopal see](/wiki/Episcopal_see "Episcopal see") of the Catholic Church, which has approximately 1.329 billion baptised [Catholics](/wiki/Catholics "Catholics") in the world as of 2018^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit)^ in the [Latin Church](/wiki/Latin_Church "Latin Church") and 23 [Eastern Catholic Churches](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches "Eastern Catholic Churches").^[\[23\]](#cite_note-33)^ The independent state of Vatican City, on the other hand, came into existence on 11 February 1929 by the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty") between the Holy See and Italy, which spoke of it as a new creation,^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Preamble-34)^ not as a vestige of the much larger [Papal States](/wiki/Papal_States "Papal States") (756--1870), which had previously encompassed much of [Central Italy](/wiki/Central_Italy "Central Italy").{#cite_ref-Preamble_34-0}

Vatican City contains religious and cultural sites such as [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica"), the [Sistine Chapel](/wiki/Sistine_Chapel "Sistine Chapel"), the [Vatican Apostolic Library](/wiki/Vatican_Library "Vatican Library"), and the [Vatican Museums](/wiki/Vatican_Museums "Vatican Museums"). They feature some of the world's most famous paintings and sculptures. The unique [economy of Vatican City](/wiki/Economy_of_Vatican_City "Economy of Vatican City") is supported financially by donations from Catholic believers, by the sale of [postage stamps](/wiki/Postage_stamp "Postage stamp") and souvenirs, fees for admission to museums, and sales of publications. Vatican City has no taxes, and items are duty-free.  

Name {#Name}
------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Name")\]

The name *[Vatican City](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Vatican_City "wikt:Vatican City")* was first used in the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty"), signed on 11 February 1929, which established the modern city-state named after [Vatican Hill](/wiki/Vatican_Hill "Vatican Hill"), the geographic location of the state within the city of [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"). "Vatican" itself is derived from the name of an [Etruscan](/wiki/Etruscan_civilization "Etruscan civilization") settlement, *Vatica* or *Vaticum*, located in the general area the Romans called *[Ager Vaticanus](/wiki/Ager_Vaticanus "Ager Vaticanus")* , "Vatican territory".^[\[25\]](#cite_note-35)^{#cite_ref-35}

The [Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language") name of the city is *Città del Vaticano* or, more formally, *Stato della Città del Vaticano*, meaning 'Vatican City State'. Its [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") name is **Status Civitatis Vaticanae** ;^[\[26\]](#cite_note-36)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-37)^ this is used in official documents by the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), the Church and the [Pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope").{#cite_ref-37}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Further information: [History of the Papacy](/wiki/History_of_the_Papacy "History of the Papacy") and [Holy See § History](/wiki/Holy_See#History "Holy See")  

### Early history {#Early_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early history")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Obelisk_of_St._Peter.jpg/180px-Obelisk_of_St._Peter.jpg)](/wiki/File:Obelisk_of_St._Peter.jpg) The [Vatican obelisk](/wiki/Vatican_obelisk "Vatican obelisk") in [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square") was brought to Rome from [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") by [Caligula](/wiki/Caligula "Caligula").

The name "Vatican" was already in use in the time of the [Roman Republic](/wiki/Roman_Republic "Roman Republic") for the *[Ager Vaticanus](/wiki/Ager_Vaticanus "Ager Vaticanus")* , a marshy area on the west bank of the [Tiber](/wiki/Tiber "Tiber") across from the city of Rome, located between the [Janiculum](/wiki/Janiculum "Janiculum"), the [Vatican Hill](/wiki/Vatican_Hill "Vatican Hill") and [Monte Mario](/wiki/Monte_Mario "Monte Mario"), down to the [Aventine Hill](/wiki/Aventine_Hill "Aventine Hill") and up to the confluence of the [Cremera](/wiki/Cremera "Cremera") creek.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Liverani_2016_21-38)^ The toponym *Ager Vaticanus* is attested until the 1st century AD: afterwards, another toponym appeared, *Vaticanus* , denoting an area much more restricted: the Vatican Hill, today's [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square"), and possibly today's [Via della Conciliazione](/wiki/Via_della_Conciliazione "Via della Conciliazione").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Liverani_2016_21-38)^ Because of its vicinity to Rome's archenemy, the [Etruscan](/wiki/Etruscan_civilization "Etruscan civilization") city of [Veii](/wiki/Veii "Veii") (another naming for the *Ager Vaticanus* was *Ripa Veientana* or *Ripa Etrusca* ), and for being subjected to the floods of the [Tiber](/wiki/Tiber "Tiber"), the Romans considered this originally uninhabited part of Rome dismal and ominous.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

The particularly low quality of Vatican wine, even after the reclamation of the area, was commented on by the poet [Martial](/wiki/Martial "Martial") ([AD](/wiki/Anno_Domini "Anno Domini") 40 -- AD 102).^[\[30\]](#cite_note-40)^ [Tacitus](/wiki/Tacitus "Tacitus") wrote that in AD 69, the [Year of the Four Emperors](/wiki/Year_of_the_Four_Emperors "Year of the Four Emperors"), when the northern army that brought [Vitellius](/wiki/Vitellius "Vitellius") to power arrived in Rome, "a large proportion camped in the unhealthy districts of the Vatican, which resulted in many deaths among the common soldiery; and the Tiber being close by, the inability of the [Gauls](/wiki/Gauls "Gauls") and Germans to bear the heat and the consequent greed with which they drank from the stream weakened their bodies, which were already an easy prey to disease".^[\[31\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Plan_of_Circus_Neronis_and_St._Peters.gif/220px-Plan_of_Circus_Neronis_and_St._Peters.gif)](/wiki/File:Plan_of_Circus_Neronis_and_St._Peters.gif) An early interpretation of the relative locations of the circus, and the [medieval](/wiki/Old_Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica "Old Saint Peter's Basilica") and [current](/wiki/St_Peter%27s_Basilica "St Peter's Basilica") Basilicas of St. Peter [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Circus_of_Nero.png/220px-Circus_of_Nero.png)](/wiki/File:Circus_of_Nero.png) One possible modern interpretation^[\[32\]](#cite_note-42)^

During the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), many villas were constructed there, after [Agrippina the Elder](/wiki/Agrippina_the_Elder "Agrippina the Elder") (14 BC -- 18 October AD 33) drained the area and laid out her gardens in the early 1st century AD. In AD 40, her son, Emperor [Caligula](/wiki/Caligula "Caligula") (31 August AD 12 -- 24 January AD 41; r. 37--41) built in her gardens a circus for charioteers (AD 40) that was later completed by [Nero](/wiki/Nero "Nero"), the *Circus Gaii et Neronis*,^[\[33\]](#cite_note-43)^ usually called, simply, the [Circus of Nero](/wiki/Circus_of_Nero "Circus of Nero").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-44)^{#cite_ref-44}

The [Vatican obelisk](/wiki/Vatican_obelisk "Vatican obelisk") in St. Peter's Square is the last visible remnant from the [Circus of Nero](/wiki/Circus_of_Nero "Circus of Nero"). It was brought from [Heliopolis](/wiki/Heliopolis_(Ancient_Egypt) "Heliopolis (Ancient Egypt)") in [Egypt](/wiki/Roman_Egypt "Roman Egypt") by Emperor [Caligula](/wiki/Caligula "Caligula"). The obelisk originally stood at the centre of the *spina* ([median](/wiki/Median_strip "Median strip")) of the [Roman circus](/wiki/Roman_circus "Roman circus").^[\[35\]](#cite_note-45)^ The circus became the site of martyrdom for many Christians after the [Great Fire of Rome](/wiki/Great_Fire_of_Rome "Great Fire of Rome") in AD 64. Tradition states that it was in this circus that [Saint Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter "Saint Peter") was [crucified upside-down](/wiki/Cross_of_St._Peter "Cross of St. Peter").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-46)^ In 1586, the obelisk was relocated to its current position by [Pope Sixtus V](/wiki/Pope_Sixtus_V "Pope Sixtus V") using a method devised by Italian architect [Domenico Fontana](/wiki/Domenico_Fontana "Domenico Fontana").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-Tafur-47)^{#cite_ref-Tafur_47-0}

Opposite the circus was a cemetery separated by the [Via Cornelia](/wiki/Via_Cornelia "Via Cornelia"). Funeral monuments and mausoleums, and small tombs, as well as altars to pagan gods of all kinds of polytheistic religions, were constructed lasting until before the construction of the [Constantinian Basilica of St. Peter](/wiki/Constantinian_Basilica_of_St._Peter "Constantinian Basilica of St. Peter") in the first half of the 4th century. A shrine dedicated to the [Phrygian](/wiki/Phrygians "Phrygians") goddess [Cybele](/wiki/Cybele "Cybele") and her consort [Attis](/wiki/Attis "Attis") remained active long after the ancient Basilica of St. Peter was built nearby.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-48)^ Remains of this ancient [necropolis](/wiki/List_of_necropoleis "List of necropoleis") were brought to light sporadically during renovations by various popes throughout the centuries, increasing in frequency during the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") until it was systematically excavated by orders of [Pope Pius XII](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII "Pope Pius XII") from 1939 to 1941. The Constantinian basilica was built in 326 over what was believed to be the [tomb of Saint Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_tomb "Saint Peter's tomb"), buried in that cemetery.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

From then on, the land mass became more populated in connection with activity at the basilica. A palace was constructed nearby as early as the 5th century during the pontificate of [Pope Symmachus](/wiki/Pope_Symmachus "Pope Symmachus") (reigned [498](/wiki/498 "498")--[514](/wiki/514 "514")).^[\[40\]](#cite_note-50)^{#cite_ref-50}  

### Papal States {#Papal_States}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Papal States")\]  
Main article: [Papal States](/wiki/Papal_States "Papal States")  
See also: [History of the Papacy](/wiki/History_of_the_Papacy "History of the Papacy")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Italy_1796.svg/170px-Italy_1796.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Italy_1796.svg) The Italian peninsula in 1796. The Papal States in central Italy are coloured purple.

Popes gradually came to have a secular role as governors of regions near Rome. They ruled the [Papal States](/wiki/Papal_States "Papal States"), which covered a large portion of the [Italian peninsula](/wiki/Italian_Peninsula "Italian Peninsula"), for more than a thousand years until the mid-19th century, when all the territory belonging to the papacy was seized by the [newly created](/wiki/Italian_unification "Italian unification") [Kingdom of Italy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy").

For most of this time, the popes did not live at the Vatican. The [Lateran Palace](/wiki/Lateran_Palace "Lateran Palace"), on the opposite side of Rome, was their habitual residence for about a thousand years. From 1309 to 1377, they lived at [Avignon](/wiki/Avignon "Avignon") in France. On their return to Rome, they chose to live at the Vatican. They moved to the [Quirinal Palace](/wiki/Quirinal_Palace "Quirinal Palace") in 1583, after work on it was completed under [Pope Paul V](/wiki/Pope_Paul_V "Pope Paul V") (1605--1621), but on the [capture of Rome](/wiki/Capture_of_Rome "Capture of Rome") in 1870 retired to the Vatican, and what had been their residence became that of the [King of Italy](/wiki/King_of_Italy "King of Italy").  

### Under Italian rule (1871--1929) {#Under_Italian_rule_.281871.E2.80.931929.29}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Under Italian rule (1871–1929)")\]  
Main article: [Roman Question](/wiki/Roman_Question "Roman Question")

In [1870](/wiki/1870 "1870"), the Pope's holdings were left in an uncertain situation when [Rome itself was annexed](/wiki/Capture_of_Rome "Capture of Rome") by Italian forces, thus bringing to completion the [Italian unification](/wiki/Italian_unification "Italian unification"), after a nominal resistance by the papal forces. Between 1861 and 1929 the status of the Pope was referred to as the "Roman Question".

Italy made no attempt to interfere with the Holy See within the Vatican walls. However, it confiscated church property in many places. In 1871, the Quirinal Palace was confiscated by the King of Italy and became the royal palace. Thereafter, the popes resided undisturbed within the Vatican walls, and certain papal prerogatives were recognised by the [Law of Guarantees](/wiki/Law_of_Guarantees "Law of Guarantees"), including the right to send and receive ambassadors. But the Popes did not recognise the Italian king's right to rule in Rome, and they refused to leave the Vatican compound until the dispute was resolved in 1929; [Pope Pius IX](/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX "Pope Pius IX") (1846--1878), the last ruler of the Papal States, was referred to as a "[prisoner in the Vatican](/wiki/Prisoner_in_the_Vatican "Prisoner in the Vatican")". Forced to give up secular power, the popes focused on spiritual issues.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-World_History-51)^{#cite_ref-World_History_51-0}  

### Lateran treaties {#Lateran_treaties}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Lateran treaties")\]  
Main article: [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty")

This situation was resolved on 11 February 1929, when the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty") between the Holy See and the Kingdom of Italy was signed by [Prime Minister and Head of Government](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy "Prime Minister of Italy") [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") on behalf of King [Victor Emmanuel III](/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III "Victor Emmanuel III") and by [Cardinal Secretary of State](/wiki/Cardinal_Secretary_of_State "Cardinal Secretary of State") [Pietro Gasparri](/wiki/Pietro_Gasparri "Pietro Gasparri") for [Pope Pius XI](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI "Pope Pius XI").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Preamble-34)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-lateran-30)^^[\[42\]](#cite_note-52)^ The treaty, which became effective on 7 June 1929, established the independent state of Vatican City and reaffirmed the special status of Catholic Christianity in Italy.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-Statute-53)^{#cite_ref-Statute_53-0}  

### World War II {#World_War_II}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: World War II")\]  
Main article: [Vatican City in World War II](/wiki/Vatican_City_in_World_War_II "Vatican City in World War II")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/The_British_Army_in_Italy_1944_NA16179.jpg/220px-The_British_Army_in_Italy_1944_NA16179.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_British_Army_in_Italy_1944_NA16179.jpg) Musicians of the [British Army](/wiki/British_Army_during_the_Second_World_War "British Army during the Second World War")'s [38th (Irish) Brigade](/wiki/38th_(Irish)_Brigade "38th (Irish) Brigade") playing in front of [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica") in June 1944

The Holy See, which governed the Vatican City, pursued a policy of neutrality during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") under the leadership of [Pope Pius XII](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII "Pope Pius XII"). Although [German](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") troops occupied Rome after the September 1943 [Armistice of Cassibile](/wiki/Armistice_of_Cassibile "Armistice of Cassibile"), with [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") forces pushing them out in 1944, both sides respected the Vatican City's status as [neutral territory](/wiki/Neutral_territory "Neutral territory").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-54)^ One of the main diplomatic priorities of Pius XII was to prevent the bombing of the city; a high level of sensitivity led him to protest even the dropping of pamphlets over Rome by the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force"), claiming that the few which landed within the Vatican City violated its neutrality.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-Chadwick1-55)^ The British government's policy towards the Vatican, as expressed in the minutes of a Cabinet meeting, was "that we should on no account molest the Vatican City, but that our action as regards the rest of Rome would depend upon how far the Italian government observed the rules of war".^[\[45\]](#cite_note-Chadwick1-55)^{#cite_ref-Chadwick1_55-1}

After the United States entered into the war, US officials were against bombing the Vatican City, fearful of offending Catholic members of the [American military](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces"), but said that "they could not stop the British from bombing Rome if the British so decided". The US military even exempted Catholic servicemembers from air raids on Rome and other areas with a significant Catholic presence, unless they voluntarily agreed to participate. Notably, with the exception of Rome, and presumably the possibility of the Vatican, no Catholic US servicemember refused a mission within German-held Italy. On the other hand, the British insisted "they would bomb Rome whenever the needs of the war demanded".^[\[46\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}

In December 1942, the British envoy to the Holy See suggested that Rome be declared an [open city](/wiki/Open_city "Open city"), a suggestion that the Holy See took more seriously than was probably meant by the envoy, who did not want Rome to be an open city, but Mussolini rejected the suggestion when the Holy See put it to him. In connection with the [Allied invasion of Sicily](/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily "Allied invasion of Sicily"), 500 [United States Army Air Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces") aircraft [bombed Rome on 19 July 1943](/wiki/Bombing_of_Rome_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Rome in World War II"), targeting the city's railway hub in particular. Approximately 1,500 people were killed, and Pius XII, who had been described in the previous month as "worried sick" about the possibility of Rome being bombed, toured the affected areas. Another Allied bombing raid took place on 13 August 1943, after Mussolini had been [ousted from power](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Fascist_regime_in_Italy "Fall of the Fascist regime in Italy").^[\[47\]](#cite_note-57)^ On the following day, the new Italian government declared Rome an open city, after consulting the Holy See on the wording of the declaration.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}  

### Post-war history {#Post-war_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Post-war history")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/St_Peter%27s_Square%2C_Vatican_City_-_April_2007.jpg/240px-St_Peter%27s_Square%2C_Vatican_City_-_April_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Peter%27s_Square,_Vatican_City_-_April_2007.jpg) View of St. Peter's Square from the top of Michelangelo's dome

Pius XII had refrained from creating [cardinals](/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholicism) "Cardinal (Catholicism)") during the war. By the end of World War II, there were several prominent vacancies: [Cardinal Secretary of State](/wiki/Cardinal_Secretary_of_State "Cardinal Secretary of State"), [Camerlengo](/wiki/Camerlengo_of_the_Holy_Roman_Church "Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church"), [Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Holy_Roman_Church "Chancellor of the Holy Roman Church"), and Prefect for the [Congregation for the Religious](/wiki/Congregation_for_Institutes_of_Consecrated_Life_and_Societies_of_Apostolic_Life "Congregation for Institutes of Consecrated Life and Societies of Apostolic Life") among them.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-59)^ Pius XII [created 32 cardinals in early 1946](/wiki/Cardinals_created_by_Pope_Pius_XII_in_1946 "Cardinals created by Pope Pius XII in 1946"), having announced his intention to do so in his preceding Christmas message.{#cite_ref-59}

The [Pontifical Military Corps](/wiki/Military_in_Vatican_City "Military in Vatican City"), except for the [Swiss Guard](/wiki/Swiss_Guard "Swiss Guard"), was disbanded by the will of [Paul VI](/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI "Pope Paul VI"), as expressed in a letter of 14 September 1970.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-Vatican_State-60)^ The [Gendarmerie Corps](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City") was transformed into a civilian [police](/wiki/Police "Police") and security force.{#cite_ref-Vatican_State_60-0}

In 1984, a new [concordat](/wiki/Concordat "Concordat") between the Holy See and Italy modified certain provisions of the earlier treaty, including the position of Catholic Christianity as the Italian state religion, a position given to it by a statute of the [Kingdom of Sardinia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sardinia_(1720%E2%80%931861) "Kingdom of Sardinia (1720–1861)") of 1848.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-Statute-53)^{#cite_ref-Statute_53-1}

Construction in 1995 of a new guest house, [Domus Sanctae Marthae](/wiki/Domus_Sanctae_Marthae "Domus Sanctae Marthae"), adjacent to St Peter's Basilica was criticized by Italian environmental groups, backed by Italian politicians. They claimed the new building would block views of the Basilica from nearby Italian apartments.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-guest_house-61)^ For a short while the plans strained the relations between the Vatican and the Italian government. The head of the Vatican's Department of Technical Services robustly rejected challenges to the Vatican State's right to build within its borders.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-guest_house-61)^{#cite_ref-guest_house_61-1}

John R. Morss writes in the *[European Journal of International Law](/wiki/European_Journal_of_International_Law "European Journal of International Law")* that due to the terms of the Lateran Treaty, Vatican City's status as a sovereign state, and the [Pope](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis")'s status as a head of state, are problematic.^\[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^^[\[52\]](#cite_note-:0-62)^{#cite_ref-:0_62-0}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Geography")\]  
Main article: [Geography of Vatican City](/wiki/Geography_of_Vatican_City "Geography of Vatican City")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Vatican_City_map_EN.svg/500px-Vatican_City_map_EN.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Vatican_City_map_EN.svg) Map of Vatican City, highlighting notable buildings and the Vatican gardens

The name "Vatican" was already in use in the time of the [Roman Republic](/wiki/Roman_Republic "Roman Republic") for the *[Ager Vaticanus](/wiki/Ager_Vaticanus "Ager Vaticanus")* , a marshy area on the west bank of the [Tiber](/wiki/Tiber "Tiber") across from the city of Rome, located between the [Janiculum](/wiki/Janiculum "Janiculum"), the [Vatican Hill](/wiki/Vatican_Hill "Vatican Hill") and [Monte Mario](/wiki/Monte_Mario "Monte Mario"), down to the [Aventine Hill](/wiki/Aventine_Hill "Aventine Hill") and up to the confluence of the [Cremera](/wiki/Cremera "Cremera") creek.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Liverani_2016_21-38)^ The territory of Vatican City is part of the Vatican Hill, and of the adjacent former Vatican Fields. It is in this territory that [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica"), the [Apostolic Palace](/wiki/Apostolic_Palace "Apostolic Palace"), the [Sistine Chapel](/wiki/Sistine_Chapel "Sistine Chapel"), and museums were built, along with various other buildings. The area was part of the Roman *[rione](/wiki/Rione "Rione")* of [Borgo](/wiki/Borgo_(rione_of_Rome) "Borgo (rione of Rome)") until 1929. Being separated from the city, on the west bank of the river Tiber, the area was an outcrop of the city that was protected by being included within the walls of [Leo IV](/wiki/Pope_Leo_IV "Pope Leo IV") (847--855), and later expanded by the current fortification walls, built under [Paul III](/wiki/Pope_Paul_III "Pope Paul III") (1534--1549), [Pius IV](/wiki/Pope_Pius_IV "Pope Pius IV") (1559--1565), and [Urban VIII](/wiki/Pope_Urban_VIII "Pope Urban VIII") (1623--1644).^[\[53\]](#cite_note-63)^{#cite_ref-63}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Vatican_City_annex.jpg/220px-Vatican_City_annex.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vatican_City_annex.jpg) Territory of Vatican City State according to the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty")

When the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty") of 1929 that gave the state its form was being prepared, the boundaries of the proposed territory were influenced by the fact that much of it was all but enclosed by this loop. For some tracts of the frontier, there was no wall, but the line of certain buildings supplied part of the boundary, and for a small part of the frontier a modern wall was constructed.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-64)^{#cite_ref-64}

The territory includes [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square"), distinguished from the territory of [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") only by a white line along the limit of the square, where it touches Piazza Pio XII. St. Peter's Square is reached through the [Via della Conciliazione](/wiki/Via_della_Conciliazione "Via della Conciliazione") which runs from close to the Tiber to St. Peter's. This grand approach was constructed by [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") after the conclusion of the Lateran Treaty.

According to the Lateran Treaty, certain [properties of the Holy See](/wiki/Properties_of_the_Holy_See "Properties of the Holy See") that are located in Italian territory, most notably the [Papal Palace of Castel Gandolfo](/wiki/Papal_Palace_of_Castel_Gandolfo "Papal Palace of Castel Gandolfo") and the [major basilicas](/wiki/Major_basilica "Major basilica"), enjoy extraterritorial status similar to that of foreign [embassies](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission").^[\[55\]](#cite_note-treaty-65)^^[\[56\]](#cite_note-treaty_text-66)^ These properties, scattered all over Rome and Italy, house essential offices and institutions necessary to the character and mission of the Holy See.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-treaty_text-66)^{#cite_ref-treaty_text_66-1}

Castel Gandolfo and the named basilicas are patrolled internally by [police agents of Vatican City State](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City") and not by [Italian police](/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy "Law enforcement in Italy"). According to the Lateran Treaty (Art. 3) St. Peter's Square, up to but not including the steps leading to the basilica, is normally patrolled by the Italian police.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-treaty-65)^{#cite_ref-treaty_65-1}

There are no passport controls for visitors entering Vatican City from the surrounding Italian territory. There is free public access to Saint Peter's Square and Basilica and, on the occasion of papal general audiences, to the hall in which they are held. For these audiences and for major ceremonies in Saint Peter's Basilica and Square, tickets free of charge must be obtained beforehand. [The Vatican Museums](/wiki/Vatican_Museums "Vatican Museums"), incorporating the Sistine Chapel, usually charge an entrance fee. There is no general public access to the gardens, but guided tours for small groups can be arranged to the gardens and excavations under the [basilica](/wiki/Basilica_of_Saint_Paul_Outside_the_Walls "Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls"). Other places are open to only those individuals who have business to transact there.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}  
[![St. Peter's Square, the basilica and obelisk, from Piazza Pio XII](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Pano-P7264747-P7264763_%283189867%29.jpg/810px-Pano-P7264747-P7264763_%283189867%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pano-P7264747-P7264763_(3189867).jpg "St. Peter's Square, the basilica and obelisk, from Piazza Pio XII")  
[](/wiki/File:Pano-P7264747-P7264763_(3189867).jpg "File:Pano-P7264747-P7264763 (3189867).jpg")  
St. Peter's Square, the basilica and obelisk, from Piazza Pio XII  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Vatican City's climate is the same as Rome's: a [temperate](/wiki/Temperate_climate "Temperate climate"), [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") *[Csa](/wiki/Hot-summer_Mediterranean_climate "Hot-summer Mediterranean climate")* with mild, rainy winters from October to mid-May and hot, dry summers from May to September. Some minor local features, principally mists and dews, are caused by the anomalous bulk of St Peter's Basilica, the elevation, the fountains, and the size of the large paved square. The highest temperature ever recorded was 40.8 °C (105.4 °F), on 28 June 2022.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-68)^{#cite_ref-68}

In July 2007, the Vatican accepted a proposal by two firms based respectively in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") and [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest"),^[\[61\]](#cite_note-71)^ whereby it would become the first [carbon neutral](/wiki/Carbon_neutrality "Carbon neutrality") state by offsetting its [carbon dioxide emissions](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions "List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions") with the creation of a [Vatican Climate Forest](/wiki/Vatican_Climate_Forest "Vatican Climate Forest") in Hungary,^[\[62\]](#cite_note-72)^ as a purely symbolic gesture^[\[63\]](#cite_note-CN070713-73)^ to encourage [Catholics](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") to do more to safeguard the planet.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-74)^ Nothing came of the project.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-75)^^[\[66\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}

On 26 November 2008, the Vatican itself put into effect a plan announced in May 2007 to cover the roof of the [Paul VI Audience Hall](/wiki/Paul_VI_Audience_Hall "Paul VI Audience Hall") with [solar panels](/wiki/Solar_panel "Solar panel").^[\[67\]](#cite_note-77)^^[\[68\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}  

### Gardens {#Gardens}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Gardens")\]  
Main article: [Gardens of Vatican City](/wiki/Gardens_of_Vatican_City "Gardens of Vatican City")

Within the territory of Vatican City are the [Vatican Gardens](/wiki/Gardens_of_Vatican_City "Gardens of Vatican City") (Italian: *Giardini Vaticani* ),^[\[69\]](#cite_note-VaticanMap-79)^ which account for about half of this territory. The gardens, established during the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") and [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") era, are decorated with fountains and sculptures.{#cite_ref-VaticanMap_79-0}

The gardens cover approximately 23 hectares (57 acres). The highest point is 60 metres (197 ft) [above mean sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level"). Stone walls bound the area in the north, south, and west.

The gardens date back to medieval times when orchards and vineyards extended to the north of the Papal [Apostolic Palace](/wiki/Apostolic_Palace "Apostolic Palace").^[\[70\]](#cite_note-Pellegrino-80)^ In 1279, [Pope Nicholas III](/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_III "Pope Nicholas III") (Giovanni Gaetano Orsini, 1277--1280) moved his residence back to the Vatican from the [Lateran Palace](/wiki/Lateran_Palace "Lateran Palace") and enclosed this area with walls.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Vatican-81)^ He planted an orchard (*pomerium* ), a lawn (*pratellum* ), and a garden (*viridarium* ).^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Vatican-81)^{#cite_ref-Vatican_81-1}

Governance {#Governance}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Governance")\]  
Main article: [Politics of Vatican City](/wiki/Politics_of_Vatican_City "Politics of Vatican City")

The politics of Vatican City takes place in the context of an [absolute](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy") [elective monarchy](/wiki/Elective_monarchy "Elective monarchy") and being governed by the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), in which the head of the Catholic Church holds power. The Pope exercises principal legislative, executive, and judicial power over the State of Vatican City, which is a rare case of a non-hereditary monarchy.  

### State and Holy See {#State_and_Holy_See}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: State and Holy See")\]

The Vatican City State, created in 1929 by the Lateran Pacts, provides the Holy See with a temporal jurisdiction and independence within a small territory. It is distinct from the Holy See. The state can thus be deemed a significant but not essential instrument of the Holy See. The Holy See itself has existed continuously as a juridical entity since Roman Imperial times and has been internationally recognised as a powerful and independent sovereign entity since [Late Antiquity](/wiki/Late_Antiquity "Late Antiquity") to the present, without interruption even at times when it was deprived of territory (e.g. 1870 to 1929).

Vatican City is one of the few widely recognised independent states that has not become a member of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations").^[\[72\]](#cite_note-82)^ The Holy See, which is distinct from Vatican City State, has [permanent observer status](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers "United Nations General Assembly observers"), with all the rights of a full member except for a vote in the [UN General Assembly](/wiki/UN_General_Assembly "UN General Assembly").{#cite_ref-82}  

### Structure {#Structure}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Structure")\]  
See also: [Pontificate](/wiki/Pontificate "Pontificate")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Portrait_of_Pope_Francis_%282021%29.jpg/170px-Portrait_of_Pope_Francis_%282021%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Pope_Francis_(2021).jpg) [Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis") in Vatican City, 2021

The government of Vatican City has a unique structure. As governed by the Holy See, the Pope is the sovereign of the state, but he is supported by different bodies. While legislative authority is also managed, in the Pope's name, by the [Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State"), a body of cardinals appointed by the Pope for five-year periods, executive power is exercised by the [president of that commission](/wiki/President_of_the_Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State") (who is consequently also the President of the Governorate), assisted by the General Secretary and the Deputy General Secretary.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-83)^^[\[74\]](#cite_note-84)^ The state's foreign relations are entrusted to the Holy See's [Secretariat of State](/wiki/Secretariat_of_State_(Holy_See) "Secretariat of State (Holy See)") and diplomatic service.{#cite_ref-84}

Nevertheless, the Pope has absolute power in the executive, legislative, and judicial branches over Vatican City,^[\[75\]](#cite_note-Vatican_City-85)^ and is thus the only absolute monarch in Europe.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}

Operationally, there are departments that deal with health, security, telecommunications and other matters.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-Vatican_City-85)^{#cite_ref-Vatican_City_85-1}  

#### Sede vacante {#Sede_vacante}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Sede vacante")\]

The [Cardinal Camerlengo](/wiki/Camerlengo_of_the_Holy_Roman_Church "Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church") presides over the [Apostolic Camera](/wiki/Apostolic_Camera "Apostolic Camera"), to which is entrusted the administration of the property and protection of other [papal temporal powers and rights](/wiki/Temporal_power_(papal) "Temporal power (papal)") of the Holy See during the period of the empty throne or [sede vacante](/wiki/Sede_vacante "Sede vacante") (papal vacancy).^[\[77\]](#cite_note-87)^ Those of the Vatican State remain under the control of the [Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State"). Acting with three other cardinals chosen by lot every three days, one from each order of cardinals ([cardinal bishop](/wiki/Cardinal_bishop "Cardinal bishop"), [cardinal priest](/wiki/Cardinal_priest "Cardinal priest"), and [cardinal deacon](/wiki/Cardinal_deacon "Cardinal deacon")), he in a sense performs during that period the functions of head of state of Vatican City.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-88)^ All the decisions these four cardinals take must be approved by the [College of Cardinals](/wiki/College_of_Cardinals "College of Cardinals") as a whole.{#cite_ref-88}  

#### Papal nobility {#Papal_nobility}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Papal nobility")\]  
Main article: [Papal nobility](/wiki/Papal_nobility "Papal nobility")

The nobility that was closely associated with the Holy See at the time of the Papal States continued to be associated with the Papal Court after the loss of these territories, generally with merely nominal duties (see [Papal Master of the Horse](/wiki/Master_of_the_Horse#Papal_Master_of_the_Horse "Master of the Horse"), [Prefecture of the Pontifical Household](/wiki/Prefecture_of_the_Pontifical_Household "Prefecture of the Pontifical Household"), [Hereditary officers of the Roman Curia](/wiki/Hereditary_officers_of_the_Roman_Curia "Hereditary officers of the Roman Curia"), [Black Nobility](/wiki/Black_Nobility "Black Nobility")). They also formed the ceremonial [Noble Guard](/wiki/Noble_Guard "Noble Guard"). In the first decades of the existence of the Vatican City State, [executive functions](/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)") were entrusted to some of them, including that of delegate for the State of Vatican City (now denominated president of the Commission for Vatican City). But with the [motu proprio](/wiki/Motu_proprio "Motu proprio") *[Pontificalis Domus](/wiki/Pontificalis_Domus "Pontificalis Domus")* of 28 March 1968,^[\[79\]](#cite_note-89)^ [Pope Paul VI](/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI "Pope Paul VI") abolished the honorary positions that had continued to exist until then, such as [Quartermaster general](/wiki/Quartermaster_general "Quartermaster general") and [Master of the Horse](/wiki/Master_of_the_Horse "Master of the Horse").{#cite_ref-89}  

### Head of state {#Head_of_state}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Head of state")\]  
Main articles: [Pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope") and [President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/President_of_the_Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State")  
See also: [List of Sovereigns of the Vatican City State](/wiki/List_of_Sovereigns_of_the_Vatican_City_State "List of Sovereigns of the Vatican City State")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/20070610_Rome_29.jpg/220px-20070610_Rome_29.jpg)](/wiki/File:20070610_Rome_29.jpg) The [Apostolic Palace](/wiki/Apostolic_Palace "Apostolic Palace") (*Palazzo Apostolico* ), the official residence of the Pope. Here, [Benedict XVI](/wiki/Benedict_XVI "Benedict XVI") is at the window marked by a maroon banner hanging from the windowsill at centre.

As Vatican City is governed by the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), the Pope is [*ex officio*](/wiki/Ex_officio_member "Ex officio member") [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state")^[\[80\]](#cite_note-90)^ of Vatican City, a function dependent on his primordial function as bishop of the [diocese of Rome](/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome "Diocese of Rome") and head of the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church").^[\[81\]](#cite_note-91)^ The term "Holy See" refers not to the Vatican state but to the Pope's spiritual and pastoral governance, largely exercised through the [Roman Curia](/wiki/Roman_Curia "Roman Curia").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-92)^ His official title with regard to Vatican City is *Sovereign of the State of the Vatican City*.{#cite_ref-92}

[Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis"), born Jorge Mario Bergoglio in [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires"), Argentina, was [elected](/wiki/Papal_conclave,_2013 "Papal conclave, 2013") on 13 March 2013. His principal subordinate government official for Vatican City as well as the country's [head of government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government") is the [President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/President_of_the_Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State"), who since 1952 exercises the functions previously belonging to the [Governor of Vatican City](/wiki/Governor_of_Vatican_City "Governor of Vatican City"). Since 2001, the president of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State also has the title of president of the Governorate of the State of Vatican City. The president is Spanish Cardinal [Fernando Vérgez Alzaga](/wiki/Fernando_V%C3%A9rgez_Alzaga "Fernando Vérgez Alzaga"), who was appointed on 1 October 2021.  

### Government and justice {#Government_and_justice}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Government and justice")\]  
See also: [Politics of Vatican City](/wiki/Politics_of_Vatican_City "Politics of Vatican City") and [Law of Vatican City](/wiki/Law_of_Vatican_City "Law of Vatican City")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Palace_of_the_Governorate._Vatican_City_State..jpg/220px-Palace_of_the_Governorate._Vatican_City_State..jpg)](/wiki/File:Palace_of_the_Governorate._Vatican_City_State..jpg) [Palace of the Governorate of Vatican City State](/wiki/Governor%27s_Palace,_Vatican "Governor's Palace, Vatican")

[Legislative](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature") functions are administered by the [Pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope") but also delegated to the [Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State"), led by the [President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/President_of_the_Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State"). Its members are cardinals appointed by the Pope for terms of five years. Acts of the commission must be approved by the Pope, through the Holy See's [Secretariat of State](/wiki/Secretariat_of_State_(Holy_See) "Secretariat of State (Holy See)")^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^, and must be published in a special appendix of the *[Acta Apostolicae Sedis](/wiki/Acta_Apostolicae_Sedis "Acta Apostolicae Sedis")* . Most of the content of this appendix consists of routine executive decrees, such as approval for a new set of postage stamps.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

[Executive authority](/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)") is delegated to the President of the Governorate of Vatican City, who is also the President of the Pontificial Commission. In addition, the Governorate include two immediate collaborators of the President: the General Secretary and the Deputy General Secretary, members of the General Secretariat, each appointed by the Pope for five-year terms^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^. Important actions of the Governorate must be confirmed by the Pontifical Commission and by the Pope through the Secretariat of State.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Both the [Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State](/wiki/Pontifical_Commission_for_Vatican_City_State "Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State") and the President of the Governorate of Vatican City can be assisted by the Councilors of Vatican City State in drafting [legislation](/wiki/Legislation "Legislation") and other important issues. The President of the Governorate can convoke the members of the Council of Directors, together with external [experts](/wiki/Expert "Expert") and people. The Governorate oversees the central governmental functions through several departments and offices.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-93)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-94)^^[\[85\]](#cite_note-95)^ The directors and officials of these offices are appointed by the Pope for five-year terms.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-95}

The Governorate is organized into central offices (one for law and another for personnel matters) and directorates with roles in the following matters:

* [Infrastructures](/wiki/Infrastructure "Infrastructure") and [services](/wiki/Public_service "Public service")
* [Telecommunications](/wiki/Telecommunications "Telecommunications") and [computer services](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology")
* [Security services](/wiki/Law_enforcement "Law enforcement") and [civil protection](/wiki/Civil_defense "Civil defense")
* [Health](/wiki/Health "Health") and [hygiene](/wiki/Hygiene "Hygiene")
* [Museums](/wiki/Museum "Museum") and [cultural heritage](/wiki/Cultural_heritage "Cultural heritage")
* Pontifical Villas^[\[86\]](#cite_note-96)^^[\[87\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}

There are also subsidiary bodies for [monetary](/wiki/Vatican_euro_coins "Vatican euro coins"), disciplinary, personnel and personnel selection matters.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}

In the Pope's name, [judiciary](/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary") functions ([Vatican judiciary](/wiki/Law_of_Vatican_City#Judiciary "Law of Vatican City")) are exercised by four bodies: a Supreme Court, a Court of Appeal, a Tribunal and a Sole Judge, whose roles are established by the Vatican codes of criminal and civil procedure, and the 2013 "[Motu Proprio](/wiki/Motu_Proprio "Motu Proprio") On the Jurisdiction of Judicial Authorities of Vatican City State in Criminal Matters".^[\[89\]](#cite_note-99)^ At the Vatican's request, sentences imposed can be served in Italy (see the [section on crime](#Crime), below).{#cite_ref-99}

Due to obvious territorial constraints, many [headquarters](/wiki/Headquarters "Headquarters") and offices of the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See") are located on [Italian](/wiki/Italy "Italy") territory, but they are granted the same immunity as [diplomatic missions](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") thanks to the [Lateran Treaty](/wiki/Lateran_Treaty "Lateran Treaty") and are commonly defined as "[extraterritorial](/wiki/Properties_of_the_Holy_See "Properties of the Holy See") areas".^[\[90\]](#cite_note-geo-100)^{#cite_ref-geo_100-0}  

### National and public security {#National_and_public_security}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: National and public security")\]  
Main articles: [Military in Vatican City](/wiki/Military_in_Vatican_City "Military in Vatican City"), [Pontifical Swiss Guard](/wiki/Pontifical_Swiss_Guard "Pontifical Swiss Guard"), [Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City"), and [Corps of Firefighters of the Vatican City State](/wiki/Corps_of_Firefighters_of_the_Vatican_City_State "Corps of Firefighters of the Vatican City State")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/20160424_035_Roma_-_Citt%C3%A0_del_Vaticano_-_Piazza_San_Pietro_%2826436304050%29.jpg/220px-20160424_035_Roma_-_Citt%C3%A0_del_Vaticano_-_Piazza_San_Pietro_%2826436304050%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:20160424_035_Roma_-_Citt%C3%A0_del_Vaticano_-_Piazza_San_Pietro_(26436304050).jpg) A guard of the Vatican at his sentry box

As Vatican City is an enclave within Italy, its military defence is provided by the [Italian Armed Forces](/wiki/Italian_Armed_Forces "Italian Armed Forces"). However, there is no formal defence treaty with Italy, as Vatican City is a [neutral state](/wiki/Neutral_state "Neutral state"). Vatican City has no armed forces of its own, although the [Swiss Guard](/wiki/Swiss_Guard "Swiss Guard") is a military corps of the Holy See responsible for the personal security of the Pope, and residents in the state. Soldiers of the Swiss Guard are entitled to hold Vatican City State passports and nationality. Swiss [mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenary "Mercenary") were historically recruited by Popes as part of an army for the Papal States, and the [Pontifical Swiss Guard](/wiki/Pontifical_Swiss_Guard "Pontifical Swiss Guard") was founded by [Pope Julius II](/wiki/Pope_Julius_II "Pope Julius II") on 22 January 1506 as the Pope's personal bodyguard and continues to fulfill that function. It is listed in the *[Annuario Pontificio](/wiki/Annuario_Pontificio "Annuario Pontificio")* under "Holy See", not under "State of Vatican City". At the end of 2005, the Guard had 134 members. Recruitment is arranged by a special agreement between the Holy See and Switzerland. All recruits must be Catholic, unmarried males with Swiss citizenship who have completed their [basic training](/wiki/Basic_training "Basic training") with the [Swiss Armed Forces](/wiki/Swiss_Armed_Forces "Swiss Armed Forces") with certificates of good conduct, be between the ages of 19 and 30, and be at least 174 cm (5 ft 9 in) in height. Members are equipped with [small arms](/wiki/Small_arms "Small arms") and the traditional [halberd](/wiki/Halberd "Halberd") (also called the Swiss voulge), and trained in bodyguarding tactics. Together with the [Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City"), the [Swiss Guard](/wiki/Swiss_Guard "Swiss Guard") have roles in the [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy")-Vatican [border control](/wiki/Border_control "Border control").^[\[90\]](#cite_note-geo-100)^ The [Palatine Guard](/wiki/Palatine_Guard "Palatine Guard") and the [Noble Guard](/wiki/Noble_Guard_(Vatican) "Noble Guard (Vatican)"), the last armed forces of the Vatican City State, were disbanded by [Pope Paul VI](/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI "Pope Paul VI") in 1970.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-Vatican_State-60)^{#cite_ref-Vatican_State_60-1}

As the entire territory of Vatican City has been listed on the International Register of Cultural Property under Special Protection and, in 1984, among [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site"), the [Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict](/wiki/Hague_Convention_for_the_Protection_of_Cultural_Property_in_the_Event_of_Armed_Conflict "Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict") provides international legal protection against [armed conflicts](/wiki/War "War").^[\[91\]](#cite_note-101)^^[\[92\]](#cite_note-102)^ A large part of the [historical documents](/wiki/Historical_document "Historical document") of the very extensive [Vatican Apostolic Archive](/wiki/Vatican_Apostolic_Archive "Vatican Apostolic Archive") is stored in the "[Bunker](/wiki/Bunker "Bunker")", which was inaugurated in 1980, a two-storey [reinforced concrete](/wiki/Reinforced_concrete "Reinforced concrete") [vault](/wiki/Bank_vault "Bank vault"), under the [Cortile della Pigna](/wiki/Cortile_della_Pigna "Cortile della Pigna"), equipped with systems for [fire protection](/wiki/Fire_protection "Fire protection"), [climate and humidity control](/wiki/Heating,_ventilation,_and_air_conditioning "Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning"), and [physical security](/wiki/Physical_security "Physical security").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Vaticano_-_Smart_elettrica_Gendarmeria_20231230.jpg/220px-Vaticano_-_Smart_elettrica_Gendarmeria_20231230.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vaticano_-_Smart_elettrica_Gendarmeria_20231230.jpg) [Gendarmerie](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City") car

Civil defence is the responsibility of the [Corps of Firefighters of the Vatican City State](/wiki/Corps_of_Firefighters_of_the_Vatican_City_State "Corps of Firefighters of the Vatican City State"), the national [fire brigade](/wiki/Fire_brigade "Fire brigade"). Dating its origins to the early nineteenth century, the Corps in its present form was established in 1941. It is responsible for fire fighting, as well as a range of civil defence scenarios including [flood](/wiki/Flood "Flood"), [natural disaster](/wiki/Natural_disaster "Natural disaster"), and [mass casualty incident](/wiki/Mass_casualty_incident "Mass casualty incident"). The Corps is governmentally supervised through the Directorate for Security Services and Civil Defence, which is also responsible for the Gendarmerie (see below).

The [Gendarmerie Corps](/wiki/Corps_of_Gendarmerie_of_Vatican_City "Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City") (*Corpo della Gendarmeria* ) is the [gendarmerie](/wiki/Gendarmerie "Gendarmerie"), or police and security force, of Vatican City and the [extraterritorial properties of the Holy See](/wiki/Extraterritorial_properties_of_the_Holy_See "Extraterritorial properties of the Holy See").^[\[94\]](#cite_note-104)^ The corps is responsible for security, [public order](/wiki/Public_order "Public order"), [border control](/wiki/Border_control "Border control"), [traffic control](/wiki/Road_traffic_control "Road traffic control"), [criminal investigation](/wiki/Criminal_procedure "Criminal procedure"), and other general police duties in Vatican City including providing security for the Pope outside of Vatican City. The corps has 130 personnel and is a part of the Directorate for Security Services and Civil Defence (which also includes the Vatican Fire Brigade), an organ of the Governorate of Vatican City.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-Gendarme-105)^^[\[96\]](#cite_note-Administrations-106)^{#cite_ref-Administrations_106-0}

Even though [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square") is part of Vatican territory, it is normally safeguarded by [Italian police forces](/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy "Law enforcement in Italy").^[\[90\]](#cite_note-geo-100)^{#cite_ref-geo_100-2}  

#### Crime {#Crime}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Crime")\]  
Main article: [Crime in Vatican City](/wiki/Crime_in_Vatican_City "Crime in Vatican City")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Crowds_in_St._Peter%27s_Square.jpg/220px-Crowds_in_St._Peter%27s_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Crowds_in_St._Peter%27s_Square.jpg) The crowds of tourists in [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square") are a target for pickpockets.

Crime in Vatican City consists largely of purse snatching, [pickpocketing](/wiki/Pickpocketing "Pickpocketing") and [shoplifting](/wiki/Shoplifting "Shoplifting") by outsiders.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-crime_rate-107)^ The tourist foot-traffic in [St. Peter's Square](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Square "St. Peter's Square") is one of the main locations for pickpockets in Vatican City.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-108)^ If crimes are committed in Saint Peter's Square, the perpetrators may be arrested and tried by the Italian authorities, since that area is normally patrolled by Italian police.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

Under the terms of article 22 of the Lateran Treaty,^[\[100\]](#cite_note-treaty1-110)^ Italy will, at the request of the Holy See, punish individuals for crimes committed within Vatican City and will itself proceed against the person who committed the offence, if that person takes refuge in Italian territory. Persons accused of crimes recognised as such both in Italy and in Vatican City that are committed in Italian territory will be handed over to the Italian authorities if they take refuge in Vatican City or in buildings that enjoy immunity under the treaty.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-treaty1-110)^^[\[101\]](#cite_note-111)^{#cite_ref-111}

Vatican City has no prison system, apart from a few detention cells for pre-trial detention.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-112)^ People convicted of committing crimes in the Vatican serve terms in [Italian](/wiki/Italy "Italy") prisons ([Polizia Penitenziaria](/wiki/Polizia_Penitenziaria "Polizia Penitenziaria")), with costs covered by the Vatican.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-113)^{#cite_ref-113}  

### Foreign relations {#Foreign_relations}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Foreign relations")\]  
See also: [Foreign relations of the Holy See](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_Holy_See "Foreign relations of the Holy See") and [List of diplomatic missions of the Holy See](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_Holy_See "List of diplomatic missions of the Holy See")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Vatican_City_-_main_entrance_with_Swiss_Guard.jpg/220px-Vatican_City_-_main_entrance_with_Swiss_Guard.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vatican_City_-_main_entrance_with_Swiss_Guard.jpg) The *Ingresso di Sant'Anna*, an entrance to Vatican City from Italy

Vatican City State is a recognised national territory under international law, but it is the Holy See that conducts diplomatic relations on its behalf, in addition to the Holy See's own diplomacy, entering into [international agreements](/wiki/Treaty "Treaty") in its regard. Vatican City thus has no diplomatic service of its own.

Because of space limitations, Vatican City is one of the few countries in the world that is unable to host embassies. Foreign embassies to the Holy See are located in the city of Rome; only during the Second World War were the staff of some embassies accredited to the Holy See given what hospitality was possible within the narrow confines of Vatican City---embassies such as that of the United Kingdom while Rome was held by the [Axis Powers](/wiki/Axis_Powers "Axis Powers") and Germany's when the Allies controlled Rome.

The size of Vatican City is thus unrelated to the large global reach exercised by the Holy See as an entity quite distinct from the state.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}

However, Vatican City State itself participates in some international organizations whose functions relate to the state as a geographical entity, distinct from the non-territorial legal persona of the Holy See. These organizations are much less numerous than those in which the Holy See participates either as a member or with observer status. They include the following eight, in each of which Vatican City State holds membership:^[\[105\]](#cite_note-Participation-115)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

* [European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations](/wiki/European_Conference_of_Postal_and_Telecommunications_Administrations "European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations") (CEPT)
* [European Telecommunications Satellite Organization](/wiki/Eutelsat "Eutelsat") (Eutelsat IGO)
* [International Grains Council](/wiki/International_Grains_Council "International Grains Council") (IGC)
* [International Institute of Administrative Sciences](/wiki/International_Institute_of_Administrative_Sciences "International Institute of Administrative Sciences") (IIAS)
* [International Telecommunication Union](/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union "International Telecommunication Union") (ITU)
* [International Telecommunications Satellite Organization](/wiki/International_Telecommunications_Satellite_Organization "International Telecommunications Satellite Organization") (ITSO)
* [Interpol](/wiki/Interpol "Interpol")^[\[107\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}
* [Universal Postal Union](/wiki/Universal_Postal_Union "Universal Postal Union") (UPU)

It also participates in:^[\[105\]](#cite_note-Participation-115)^{#cite_ref-Participation_115-1}

* [World Medical Association](/wiki/World_Medical_Association "World Medical Association")
* [World Intellectual Property Organization](/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Organization "World Intellectual Property Organization") (WIPO)

#### Non-party, non-signatory policy {#Non-party.2C_non-signatory_policy}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Non-party, non-signatory policy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/United_Nations_members_de_facto_borders.svg/220px-United_Nations_members_de_facto_borders.svg.png)](/wiki/File:United_Nations_members_de_facto_borders.svg) Image of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") member state borders on a map

The Vatican City is not a member of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") (UN), but was granted observer status to the [United Nations General Assembly](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly "United Nations General Assembly") in 1968; the only other country in a similar position is the partially recognised [State of Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine"). Since it is not a member of the UN, the Vatican City is not subjected to the jurisdiction of the [International Court of Justice](/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice "International Court of Justice") (ICJ). It does, however, engage with various UN specialized agencies through its observer status including the [Central Emergency Response Fund](/wiki/Central_Emergency_Response_Fund "Central Emergency Response Fund"), to which it contributed US$20,000 between 2006 and 2022.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The Vatican City State is not a member of the [International Criminal Court](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court "International Criminal Court") (ICC). In Europe, only [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus "Belarus") is also a non-party, non-signatory state, while Ukraine and [Monaco](/wiki/Monaco "Monaco") are signatory states that have not ratified and Russia withdrew from it in 2016.

The Vatican City State is not a member of the [European Court of Human Rights](/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights "European Court of Human Rights"). Among European states, Belarus is also not a member, while Russia has ceased to be part of it after being expelled from the [Council of Europe](/wiki/Council_of_Europe "Council of Europe") following the [2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine").

The [OECD](/wiki/OECD "OECD")'s "[Common Reporting Standard](/wiki/Common_Reporting_Standard "Common Reporting Standard")" (CRS), aiming at preventing [tax evasion](/wiki/Tax_evasion "Tax evasion") and [money laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering "Money laundering"), has also not been signed.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[110\]](#cite_note-120)^^[\[111\]](#cite_note-121)^ The Vatican City State has been criticized for money laundering practises in the past decades.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[113\]](#cite_note-123)^^[\[114\]](#cite_note-124)^ The only other country in Europe that has not agreed to sign the CRS is Belarus.{#cite_ref-124}

The Vatican City State is also one of few countries in the world that does not provide any publicly available financial data to the International Monetary Fund.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-125)^{#cite_ref-125}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Vatican City](/wiki/Economy_of_Vatican_City "Economy of Vatican City")

The Vatican City State budget includes the [Vatican Museums](/wiki/Vatican_Museums "Vatican Museums") and post office and is supported financially by the sale of [stamps](/wiki/Postage_stamps_and_postal_history_of_Vatican_City "Postage stamps and postal history of Vatican City"), [coins](/wiki/Vatican_euro_coins "Vatican euro coins"), medals and tourist mementos; by fees for admission to museums; and by publications sales.^[\[k\]](#cite_note-126)^ The incomes and living standards of lay workers are comparable to those of counterparts who work in the city of Rome.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-economy_factbook-127)^ Other industries include printing, the production of mosaics, and the manufacture of staff uniforms.{#cite_ref-economy_factbook_127-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Musei_Vaticani._Braccio_Nuovo.JPG/220px-Musei_Vaticani._Braccio_Nuovo.JPG)](/wiki/File:Musei_Vaticani._Braccio_Nuovo.JPG) Vatican Museums' "New Wing", built by [Raffaele Stern](/wiki/Raffaele_Stern "Raffaele Stern") (1774--1820)

The [Institute for Works of Religion](/wiki/Institute_for_Works_of_Religion "Institute for Works of Religion") (IOR, *Istituto per le Opere di Religione* ), also known as the Vatican Bank, is a financial agency situated in the Vatican that conducts worldwide financial activities. It has multilingual [ATMs](/wiki/Automated_teller_machine "Automated teller machine") with instructions in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"), possibly the only ATM in the world with this feature.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-Seans-128)^{#cite_ref-Seans_128-0}

Vatican City issues its own coins and stamps. It has used the euro as its currency since 1 January 1999, owing to a special agreement with the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (council decision 1999/98/EC). Euro coins and notes were introduced on 1 January 2002---the Vatican does not issue [euro banknotes](/wiki/Euro_banknotes "Euro banknotes"). Issuance of euro-denominated coins is strictly limited by treaty, though somewhat more than usual is allowed in a year in which there is a change in the papacy.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-129)^ Because of their rarity, [Vatican euro coins](/wiki/Vatican_euro_coins "Vatican euro coins") are highly sought by collectors.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-130)^ Until the adoption of the Euro, Vatican coinage and stamps were denominated in their own [Vatican lira](/wiki/Vatican_lira "Vatican lira") currency, which was on par with the Italian [lira](/wiki/Lira "Lira").{#cite_ref-130}

Vatican City State, which employs nearly 2,000 people, had a surplus of 6.7 million euros in 2007 but ran a deficit in 2008 of over 15 million euros.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-131)^{#cite_ref-131}

In 2012, the US Department of State's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report listed Vatican City for the first time among the nations of concern for [money-laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering "Money laundering"), placing it in the middle category, which includes countries such as Ireland, but not among the most vulnerable countries, which include the United States itself, Germany, Italy, and Russia.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

On 24 February 2014, the Vatican announced it was establishing a secretariat for the economy, to be responsible for all economic, financial, and administrative activities of the Holy See and the Vatican City State, headed by Cardinal [George Pell](/wiki/George_Pell "George Pell"). This followed the charging of two senior clerics including a [monsignor](/wiki/Monsignor "Monsignor") with money laundering offences. Pope Francis also appointed an auditor-general authorized to carry out random audits of any agency at any time and engaged a US financial services company to review the Vatican's 19,000 accounts to ensure compliance with international money laundering practices. The pontiff also ordered that the [Administration of the Patrimony of the Apostolic See](/wiki/Administration_of_the_Patrimony_of_the_Apostolic_See "Administration of the Patrimony of the Apostolic See") would be the Vatican's central bank, with responsibilities similar to other central banks around the world.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-VaticanEconomicSecretariat-133)^{#cite_ref-VaticanEconomicSecretariat_133-0}

In 2022, the Vatican planned to release [NFTs](/wiki/NFT "NFT") of its museum collection.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-134)^{#cite_ref-134}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Demographics")\]  
See also: [Women in Vatican City](/wiki/Women_in_Vatican_City "Women in Vatican City")

As of 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit)^, Vatican City has a population of 764 residents, regardless of citizenship.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-population-16)^ There are also 372 Vatican citizens residing elsewhere,^[\[13\]](#cite_note-population-16)^ consisting of diplomats of the Holy See to other countries and cardinals residing in Rome.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-citizenship-135)^{#cite_ref-citizenship_135-0}

The population is composed of clergy, other religious members, laypeople serving the state (such as the Swiss Guard) and their family members.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-population2011-136)^ In 2013 there were 13 families of the employees of the Holy See living in Vatican City,^[\[126\]](#cite_note-137)^ in 2019 there were 20 children of the Swiss Guards living at the Vatican.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-138)^ All citizens, residents, and places of worship in the city are [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"). The city also receives thousands of tourists and workers every day.{#cite_ref-138}

### Languages {#Languages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Languages")\]  
Further information: [Languages of Vatican City](/wiki/Languages_of_Vatican_City "Languages of Vatican City")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Seal_of_Vatican_City.svg/220px-Seal_of_Vatican_City.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Seal_of_Vatican_City.svg) The Seal of Vatican City. Note the use of the Italian language.

Vatican City has no formally enacted [official language](/wiki/Official_language "Official language"), but, unlike the Holy See which most often uses [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") for the authoritative version of its official documents, Vatican City uses only Italian in its legislation and official communications.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-139)^ Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state. In the Swiss Guard, Swiss German is the language used for giving commands, but the individual guards take their oath of loyalty in their own languages: German, French, Italian or [Romansh](/wiki/Romansh_language "Romansh language"). The official websites of the Holy See^[\[129\]](#cite_note-140)^ and of Vatican City^[\[130\]](#cite_note-141)^ are primarily in Italian, with versions of their pages in a large number of languages to varying extents.{#cite_ref-141}  

### Citizenship {#Citizenship}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Citizenship")\]

Unlike [citizenship](/wiki/Citizenship "Citizenship") of other states, which is based either on *[jus sanguinis](/wiki/Jus_sanguinis "Jus sanguinis")* (birth from a citizen, even outside the state's territory) or on *[jus soli](/wiki/Jus_soli "Jus soli")* (birth within the territory of the state), citizenship of Vatican City is granted on *jus officii* , namely on the grounds of appointment to work in a certain capacity in the service of the Holy See. It usually ceases upon cessation of the appointment. Citizenship is also extended to the spouse and children of a citizen, provided that they are living together in the city.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-citizenship-135)^ Some individuals are also authorized to reside in the city but do not qualify or choose not to request citizenship.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-citizenship-135)^ Anyone who loses Vatican citizenship and does not possess other citizenship automatically becomes an [Italian citizen](/wiki/Italian_citizenship "Italian citizenship") as provided in the Lateran Treaty.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-treaty-65)^{#cite_ref-treaty_65-2}

The Holy See, not being a country, issues only [diplomatic](/wiki/Diplomatic_passport "Diplomatic passport") and [service](/wiki/Service_passport "Service passport") passports, whereas Vatican City issues [normal](/wiki/Ordinary_passport "Ordinary passport") [passports](/wiki/Vatican_and_Holy_See_passports "Vatican and Holy See passports") for its citizens.  

### Statistical oddities {#Statistical_oddities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Statistical oddities")\]

In statistics comparing countries in various [per capita](/wiki/Per_capita "Per capita") or per area metrics, Vatican City is often an outlier---these can stem from the state's small size and ecclesiastical function.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-:1-142)^ For example, as most of the roles which would confer citizenship are reserved for men, the gender ratio of the citizenship is several men per woman.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-143)^ Further oddities are petty crimes against tourists resulting in a very high per-capita crime rate,^[\[133\]](#cite_note-144)^ and the city-state leading the world in per-capita wine consumption due to its [sacramental use](/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church "Sacraments of the Catholic Church").^[\[131\]](#cite_note-:1-142)^ A jocular illustration of these anomalies is sometimes made by calculating a "Popes per km^2^" statistic, which is greater than two because the country is less than half a square kilometre in area.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}
