### Cultural heritage {#Cultural_heritage}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Cultural heritage")\]  
See also: [Architecture of Vatican City](/wiki/Architecture_of_Vatican_City "Architecture of Vatican City") and [Vatican Museums](/wiki/Vatican_Museums "Vatican Museums")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Basilica_di_San_Pietro_in_Vaticano_September_2015-1a.jpg/220px-Basilica_di_San_Pietro_in_Vaticano_September_2015-1a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Basilica_di_San_Pietro_in_Vaticano_September_2015-1a.jpg) [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica") is one of the most renowned works of Renaissance architecture.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-w583-146)^

Vatican City is home to some of the most famous art in the world. [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica"), designed by a succession of architects including [Bramante](/wiki/Bramante "Bramante"), [Michelangelo](/wiki/Michelangelo "Michelangelo"), [Giacomo della Porta](/wiki/Giacomo_della_Porta "Giacomo della Porta"), [Maderno](/wiki/Carlo_Maderno "Carlo Maderno") and [Bernini](/wiki/Bernini "Bernini"), is a renowned work of [Renaissance architecture](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture"). The [Sistine Chapel](/wiki/Sistine_Chapel "Sistine Chapel") is famous for its frescos, which include works by [Perugino](/wiki/Perugino "Perugino"), [Domenico Ghirlandaio](/wiki/Domenico_Ghirlandaio "Domenico Ghirlandaio") and [Botticelli](/wiki/Botticelli "Botticelli"), as well as the [ceiling](/wiki/Sistine_Chapel_ceiling "Sistine Chapel ceiling") and [Last Judgment](/wiki/Last_Judgment "Last Judgment") by Michelangelo. The interiors of the Vatican were decorated by artists including [Raphael](/wiki/Raphael "Raphael") and [Fra Angelico](/wiki/Fra_Angelico "Fra Angelico").

The [Vatican Apostolic Library](/wiki/Vatican_Apostolic_Library "Vatican Apostolic Library") and the collections of the [Vatican Museums](/wiki/Vatican_Museums "Vatican Museums") are of the highest historical, scientific and cultural importance.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-147)^ Added by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") to the List of [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1984, the Vatican is the only site to consist of an entire state.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-148)^ Furthermore, it is the only UNESCO site registered as a *centre containing monuments* in the "International Register of Cultural Property under Special Protection" according to the 1954 [Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict](/wiki/Hague_Convention_for_the_Protection_of_Cultural_Property_in_the_Event_of_Armed_Conflict "Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict").^[\[137\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-148)^{#cite_ref-UNESCO_148-1}  

### Science {#Science}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Science")\]

Following in the footsteps of the [Pontifical Academy of New Lincei](/wiki/Accademia_dei_Lincei "Accademia dei Lincei") founded by [Pope Pius IX](/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX "Pope Pius IX") in 1847, [Pope Pius XI](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI "Pope Pius XI") gave birth to the [Pontifical Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Pontifical_Academy_of_Sciences "Pontifical Academy of Sciences") in 1936, which, located in the [Casina Pio IV](/wiki/Casina_Pio_IV "Casina Pio IV"), guarantees [academic freedom](/wiki/Academic_freedom "Academic freedom") to contribute to [mathematical](/wiki/Mathematical_sciences "Mathematical sciences"), [physical](/wiki/Outline_of_physical_science "Outline of physical science") (including [astronomy](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy"), [Earth sciences](/wiki/Earth_sciences "Earth sciences"), [physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics") and [chemistry](/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry")) and [natural sciences](/wiki/Natural_sciences "Natural sciences") (e.g., [medicine](/wiki/Medicine "Medicine"), [neuroscience](/wiki/Neuroscience "Neuroscience"), [biology](/wiki/Biology "Biology"), [genetics](/wiki/Genetics "Genetics"), [biochemistry](/wiki/Biochemistry "Biochemistry")), and confront [epistemological](/wiki/Epistemology "Epistemology") issues, with interests also in the [history of science](/wiki/History_of_science "History of science"). Among the [academicians](/wiki/Academician "Academician"), there are or were the [astrophysicist](/wiki/Astrophysicist "Astrophysicist") [Martin John Rees](/wiki/Martin_John_Rees "Martin John Rees"), the [mathematician](/wiki/Mathematician "Mathematician") [Cédric Villani](/wiki/C%C3%A9dric_Villani "Cédric Villani"), the [theoretical physicist](/wiki/Theoretical_physics "Theoretical physics") [Edward Witten](/wiki/Edward_Witten "Edward Witten"), the [Nobel Prize in Chemistry](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry "Nobel Prize in Chemistry") laureates [Jennifer Doudna](/wiki/Jennifer_Doudna "Jennifer Doudna") and [Emmanuelle Charpentier](/wiki/Emmanuelle_Charpentier "Emmanuelle Charpentier"), and [Ernest Rutherford](/wiki/Ernest_Rutherford "Ernest Rutherford"), the [geneticists](/wiki/Genetics "Genetics") [Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza](/wiki/Luigi_Luca_Cavalli-Sforza "Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza") and [Francis Collins](/wiki/Francis_Collins "Francis Collins"), the [head transplant](/wiki/Head_transplant "Head transplant") pioneer [Robert J. White](/wiki/Robert_J._White "Robert J. White"), the [Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine "Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine") [Alexander Fleming](/wiki/Alexander_Fleming "Alexander Fleming").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-149)^^[\[139\]](#cite_note-150)^{#cite_ref-150}

The [Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences](/wiki/Pontifical_Academy_of_Social_Sciences "Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences") is another [pontifical academy](/wiki/Pontifical_academy "Pontifical academy") of the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See") located in Vatican City, which deals also with [anthropology](/wiki/Anthropology "Anthropology"), [communication studies](/wiki/Communication_studies "Communication studies"), [information sciences](/wiki/Information_sciences "Information sciences"), [cybernetics](/wiki/Cybernetics "Cybernetics"), [economics](/wiki/Economics "Economics"), [education](/wiki/Education "Education"), [geography](/wiki/Geography "Geography"), [history](/wiki/History "History"), [law](/wiki/Law "Law"), [linguistics](/wiki/Linguistics "Linguistics"), [political science](/wiki/Political_science "Political science"), [psychology](/wiki/Psychology "Psychology"), [behavioral sciences](/wiki/Behavioral_sciences "Behavioral sciences"), [sociology](/wiki/Sociology "Sociology") and [demography](/wiki/Demography "Demography").^[\[140\]](#cite_note-151)^ The seat of the [Pontifical Academy for Life](/wiki/Pontifical_Academy_for_Life "Pontifical Academy for Life"), whose domains are [bioethics](/wiki/Bioethics "Bioethics") and [ethics of technology](/wiki/Ethics_of_technology "Ethics of technology"), is at [San Callisto complex](/wiki/Palazzo_San_Callisto "Palazzo San Callisto"), a Vatican [extraterritorial property](/wiki/Properties_of_the_Holy_See#Outside_Vatican_City_but_inside_Rome "Properties of the Holy See").^[\[141\]](#cite_note-152)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}

Some of the Vatican telescopes of the [astronomical](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy") institution named [Vatican Observatory](/wiki/Vatican_Observatory "Vatican Observatory") participated in creating the [Carte du Ciel](/wiki/Carte_du_Ciel "Carte du Ciel"), but they have progressively become useless or limited for [research](/wiki/Research "Research") purposes due to [light pollution](/wiki/Light_pollution "Light pollution") in their locations: Vatican City (the [Gardens of Vatican City](/wiki/Gardens_of_Vatican_City "Gardens of Vatican City") and near [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica")) and the Vatican [extraterritorial](/wiki/Properties_of_the_Holy_See#Outside_Rome "Properties of the Holy See") [Palace of Castel Gandolfo](/wiki/Palace_of_Castel_Gandolfo "Palace of Castel Gandolfo"). However, the [Vatican Observatory](/wiki/Vatican_Observatory "Vatican Observatory"), whose origins date back to the 16th century, continues to contribute to astronomical research, especially through a partnership with the [University of Arizona](/wiki/University_of_Arizona "University of Arizona") and the [infrared](/wiki/Infrared_astronomy "Infrared astronomy") and [optical](/wiki/Visible-light_astronomy "Visible-light astronomy") [Vatican Advanced Technology Telescope](/wiki/Vatican_Advanced_Technology_Telescope "Vatican Advanced Technology Telescope") in [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), and to astronomical [education](/wiki/Education "Education") and "[popular science](/wiki/Popular_science "Popular science")" projects. As a member of the [International Astronomical Union](/wiki/International_Astronomical_Union "International Astronomical Union") and the [International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics](/wiki/International_Center_for_Relativistic_Astrophysics "International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics"), it deals also with research on [cosmological models](/wiki/Physical_cosmology "Physical cosmology"), [stellar classification](/wiki/Stellar_classification "Stellar classification"), [binary stars](/wiki/Binary_star "Binary star"), and [nebulae](/wiki/Nebulae "Nebulae"). In addition, it has contributed to [philosophical](/wiki/Philosophy "Philosophy") [interdisciplinary](/wiki/Interdisciplinary "Interdisciplinary") studies at the [Center for Theology and the Natural Sciences](/wiki/Graduate_Theological_Union "Graduate Theological Union") in [Berkeley, California](/wiki/Berkeley,_California "Berkeley, California") and research on the [history of astronomy](/wiki/History_of_astronomy "History of astronomy") thanks to its extensive library, which also includes a [meteorite](/wiki/Meteorite "Meteorite") [collection](/wiki/Collection_(museum) "Collection (museum)").^[\[143\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}  

### Sport {#Sport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Sport")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Vatican City](/wiki/Sport_in_Vatican_City "Sport in Vatican City")

Vatican City is not a member of the [International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee") and does not compete in the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"), though it has participated in some international sporting events, including the [World Cycling Championships](/wiki/World_Cycling_Championships "World Cycling Championships"),^[\[144\]](#cite_note-Pender_2022-155)^ the [Championships of the Small States of Europe](/wiki/Championships_of_the_Small_States_of_Europe "Championships of the Small States of Europe") and the [Mediterranean Games](/wiki/Mediterranean_Games "Mediterranean Games").^[\[145\]](#cite_note-Med_Games-156)^ The country has its own athletics association, [Athletica Vaticana](/wiki/Athletica_Vaticana "Athletica Vaticana").^[\[146\]](#cite_note-LOsservatore_Romano_2023_a014-157)^{#cite_ref-LOsservatore_Romano_2023_a014_157-0}

[Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") in Vatican City is organized by the [Vatican Amateur Sports Association](/wiki/Vatican_Amateur_Sports_Association "Vatican Amateur Sports Association"), which holds the national championship, called the [Vatican City Championship](/wiki/Vatican_City_Championship "Vatican City Championship"), with eight teams, including, for example, the Swiss Guard's [FC Guardia](/wiki/FC_Guardia "FC Guardia") and police and museum guard teams.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-158)^ The association also organizes the [Coppa Sergio Valci](/wiki/Coppa_Sergio_Valci "Coppa Sergio Valci") and the [Vatican Supercoppa](/wiki/Supercoppa_(Vatican_City) "Supercoppa (Vatican City)"). It controls the [Vatican City national football team](/wiki/Vatican_City_national_football_team "Vatican City national football team"), which is neither affiliated with [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") nor [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA").{#cite_ref-158}  

Infrastructure and public services {#Infrastructure_and_public_services}
------------------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Infrastructure and public services")\]  

### Transport {#Transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Vatican City](/wiki/Transport_in_Vatican_City "Transport in Vatican City")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/0_Gare_du_Vatican.JPG/220px-0_Gare_du_Vatican.JPG)](/wiki/File:0_Gare_du_Vatican.JPG) The [shortest national railway system](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Vatican_City "Rail transport in Vatican City") in the world

Vatican City has a reasonably well-developed transport network considering its size (consisting mostly of a piazza and walkways). As a state that is 1.05 kilometres (1,150 yards) long and 0.85 km (930 yd) wide,^[\[148\]](#cite_note-159)^ it has a small [transportation system](/wiki/Transport_network "Transport network") with no airports or highways.{#cite_ref-159}

The only [aviation](/wiki/Aviation "Aviation") facility in Vatican City is the [Vatican City Heliport](/wiki/Vatican_City_Heliport "Vatican City Heliport"). Vatican City is one of the few independent [countries without an airport](/wiki/List_of_countries_without_an_airport "List of countries without an airport"), and is served by the airports that serve the city of Rome, [Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport](/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci-Fiumicino_Airport "Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport") and to a lesser extent [Ciampino Airport](/wiki/Rome_Ciampino_Airport "Rome Ciampino Airport").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-Sinfin-160)^{#cite_ref-Sinfin_160-0}

There is a [standard gauge](/wiki/Standard_gauge "Standard gauge") [Vatican Railway](/wiki/Vatican_Railway "Vatican Railway") and a [Vatican City railway station](/wiki/Vatican_City_railway_station "Vatican City railway station"), mainly used to transport freight, connected to Italy's network at Rome's [Roma San Pietro railway station](/wiki/Roma_San_Pietro_railway_station "Roma San Pietro railway station") by an 852-metre-long (932 yd) spur, 300 metres (330 yd) of which is within Vatican territory.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-Sinfin-160)^ [Pope John XXIII](/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII "Pope John XXIII") was the first Pope to make use of the railway; [Pope John Paul II](/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II "Pope John Paul II") rarely used it.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-Sinfin-160)^{#cite_ref-Sinfin_160-2}

The closest [metro](/wiki/Rome_Metro "Rome Metro") station is [Ottaviano -- San Pietro -- Musei Vaticani](/wiki/Ottaviano_%E2%80%93_San_Pietro_%E2%80%93_Musei_Vaticani_(Rome_Metro) "Ottaviano – San Pietro – Musei Vaticani (Rome Metro)").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}  

### Telecommunications and mass media {#Telecommunications_and_mass_media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Telecommunications and mass media")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Pay_phone_in_the_Vatican_City.jpg/220px-Pay_phone_in_the_Vatican_City.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pay_phone_in_the_Vatican_City.jpg) Pay phone in the Vatican City

The City is served by an independent, modern telephone system named the [Vatican Telephone Service](/wiki/Vatican_Telephone_Service "Vatican Telephone Service").^[\[151\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}

The Vatican also controls its own Internet [top-level domain](/wiki/Top-level_domain "Top-level domain"), which is registered as ([.va](/wiki/.va ".va")). Broadband service is widely provided within Vatican City. Vatican City has also been given a radio [ITU prefix](/wiki/ITU_prefix "ITU prefix"), HV, and this is sometimes used by [amateur radio](/wiki/Amateur_radio "Amateur radio") operators.

[Vatican Radio](/wiki/Vatican_Radio "Vatican Radio"), which was organized by [Guglielmo Marconi](/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi "Guglielmo Marconi"), broadcasts on [short-wave](/wiki/Shortwave "Shortwave"), [medium-wave](/wiki/Medium_wave "Medium wave") and FM frequencies and on the Internet.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-163)^ Its main transmission antennae are located in Italian territory, and exceed Italian environmental protection levels of emission. For this reason, the Vatican Radio has been [sued](/wiki/Vatican_Radio_lawsuit "Vatican Radio lawsuit"). Television services are provided through another entity, the [Vatican Television Center](/wiki/Vatican_Television_Center "Vatican Television Center").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}

*[L'Osservatore Romano](/wiki/L%27Osservatore_Romano "L'Osservatore Romano")* is the multilingual semi-official newspaper of the Holy See. It is published by a private corporation under the direction of Catholic laymen, but reports on official information. However, the official texts of documents are in the *[Acta Apostolicae Sedis](/wiki/Acta_Apostolicae_Sedis "Acta Apostolicae Sedis")* , the [official gazette](/wiki/Gazette "Gazette") of the Holy See, which has an appendix for documents of the Vatican City State.

Vatican Radio, the Vatican Television Center, and L'Osservatore Romano are organs not of the Vatican State but of the Holy See, and are listed as such in the *[Annuario Pontificio](/wiki/Annuario_Pontificio "Annuario Pontificio")* , which places them in the section "Institutions linked with the Holy See", ahead of the sections on the Holy See's diplomatic service abroad and the [diplomatic corps](/wiki/Diplomatic_corps "Diplomatic corps") accredited to the Holy See, after which is placed the section on the State of Vatican City.  

### Postal service {#Postal_service}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Postal service")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Poste_Vaticane.jpg/220px-Poste_Vaticane.jpg)](/wiki/File:Poste_Vaticane.jpg) The Vatican's post office was established on 11 February 1929.

A [postal system](/wiki/Mail "Mail") ([Poste Vaticane](/wiki/Poste_Vaticane "Poste Vaticane")) was created on 13 February 1929. On 1 August, the state started to release its own postal stamps, under the authority of the [Philatelic and Numismatic Office of the Vatican City State](/wiki/Philatelic_and_Numismatic_Office_of_the_Vatican_City_State "Philatelic and Numismatic Office of the Vatican City State").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-165)^ The city's postal service is sometimes said to be "the best in the world",^[\[155\]](#cite_note-NYT-166)^ and faster than the postal service in Rome.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-NYT-166)^{#cite_ref-NYT_166-1}

The [international postal country code prefix](/wiki/Postal_code#Country_code_prefixes "Postal code") is *SCV* , and the only postal code is *00120* -- altogether *SCV-00120* .^[\[156\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}  

### Healthcare {#Healthcare}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Healthcare")\]  
See also: [Vatican Pharmacy](/wiki/Vatican_Pharmacy "Vatican Pharmacy") and [Bambino Gesù Hospital](/wiki/Bambino_Ges%C3%B9_Hospital "Bambino Gesù Hospital")  

### Recycling {#Recycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Recycling")\]

In 2008, the Vatican began an "ecological island" for renewable waste and has continued the initiative throughout the papacy of [Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis"). These innovations included, for example, the installation of a solar power system on the roof of the [Paul VI Audience Hall](/wiki/Paul_VI_Audience_Hall "Paul VI Audience Hall"). In July 2019, it was announced that Vatican City would ban the use and sale of [single-use plastics](/wiki/Single-use_plastic "Single-use plastic") as soon as its supply was depleted, well before the 2021 deadline established by the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"). It is estimated that 50--55% of Vatican City's municipal solid waste is properly sorted and recycled, with the goal of reaching the EU standard of 70--75%.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-end_sale_of_single-use_plastics-168)^{#cite_ref-end_sale_of_single-use_plastics_168-0}

### Footnotes {#Footnotes}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vatican_City&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Footnotes")\]  
1. **[\^](#cite_ref-4)** Many other languages are used by institutions situated within the state, such as the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), the [Pontifical Swiss Guard](/wiki/Pontifical_Guard "Pontifical Guard"), and the [Pontifical Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Pontifical_Academy_of_Sciences "Pontifical Academy of Sciences").  
   The Holy See uses [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") as its official language and Italian as its main working and diplomatic language; in addition, its [Secretariat of State](/wiki/Secretariat_of_State_(Holy_See) "Secretariat of State (Holy See)") uses [English](/wiki/English_language "English language"), [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"), German, Italian, [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"), [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language") and [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"). The Swiss Guard has three command languages: German, French and Italian; the chaplain of the guard reads aloud the full oath of allegiance in these three languages.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)^{#cite_ref-3}
{#cite_note-4}
2. **[\^](#cite_ref-12)** All powers delegated by the sovereign^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^{#cite_ref-11}
{#cite_note-12}
3. \^ [^***a***^](#cite_ref-area_15-0) [^***b***^](#cite_ref-area_15-1) The [De Agostini Atlas Calendar](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calendario_Atlante_De_Agostini "it:Calendario Atlante De Agostini") listed the area of Vatican City as 44 ha in its 1930 edition^[\[11\]](#cite_note-13)^ but corrected it to 49 ha in its 1945--1946 edition.^[\[12\]](#cite_note-agostini1945-14)^ The figure of 44 ha is still widely cited by many sources despite its inaccuracy.{#cite_ref-agostini1945_14-0}
{#cite_note-area-15}
4. **[\^](#cite_ref-17)** Visitors and tourists are not permitted to drive inside Vatican City without specific permission, which is normally granted only to those on official business in Vatican City.{#cite_note-17}
{#cite_note-17}
5. **[\^](#cite_ref-18)** [ITU-T](/wiki/ITU-T "ITU-T") assigned code 379 to Vatican City. However, Vatican City is included in the Italian telephone numbering plan and uses the Italian country code 39, followed by 06 (for Rome) and 698.{#cite_note-18}
{#cite_note-18}
6. **[\^](#cite_ref-19)** [/ˈvætɪkənˈsɪti/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/32/En-us-Vatican_City.ogg/En-us-Vatican_City.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:En-us-Vatican_City.ogg "File:En-us-Vatican City.ogg")^{#ooui-php-1}
{#cite_note-19}
7. **[\^](#cite_ref-22)** *Stato della Città del Vaticano*^[\[14\]](#cite_note-20)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-21)^ ( Italian pronunciation: [\[ˈstaːto della tʃitˈta ddel vatiˈkaːno\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Italian "Help:IPA/Italian")) is the name used in [the text](https://web.archive.org/web/20120822001817/https://www.vatican.va/vatican_city_state/legislation/documents/scv_doc_20001126_legge-fondamentale-scv_it.html) of the state's [Fundamental Law](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") and in [the state's official website](https://www.vaticanstate.va/content/vaticanstate/en.html).{#cite_ref-21}
{#cite_note-22}
8. **[\^](#cite_ref-23)** The [ecclesiastical](/wiki/Latin_spelling_and_pronunciation#Ecclesiastical_pronunciation "Latin spelling and pronunciation"), and therefore official, pronunciation is [\[ˈstatus tʃiviˈtatis vatiˈkane\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Latin "Help:IPA/Latin"); the [classical](/wiki/Latin_spelling_and_pronunciation#Classical_pronunciation "Latin spelling and pronunciation") one is [\[ˈstatʊs kiːwɪˈtaːtɪs waːtɪˈkaːnae̯\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Latin "Help:IPA/Latin").{#cite_note-23}
{#cite_note-23}
9. **[\^](#cite_ref-24)** In the languages used by the [Secretariat of State](/wiki/Secretariat_of_State_(Holy_See) "Secretariat of State (Holy See)") of the [Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See") (except English and Italian as already mentioned above):
   * [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): *Cité du Vatican* ---*État de la Cité du Vatican*
   * [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"): *Vatikanstadt* , cf. *Vatikan*---*Staat Vatikanstadt* (in Austria: *Staat der Vatikanstadt*)
   * [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"): *Miasto Watykańskie* , cf. *Watykan*---*Państwo Watykańskie*
   * [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Cidade do Vaticano* ---*Estado da Cidade do Vaticano*
   * [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): *Ciudad del Vaticano* ---*Estado de la Ciudad del Vaticano*.
   {#cite_note-24}
{#cite_note-24}
10. **[\^](#cite_ref-29)** The Holy See is the central governing body of the Catholic Church and Vatican City and a sovereign entity recognised by international law, consisting of the Pope and the [Roman Curia](/wiki/Roman_Curia "Roman Curia"). It is also metonymically referred to as "The Vatican".{#cite_note-29}
{#cite_note-29}
11. **[\^](#cite_ref-126)** The Holy See's budget, which is distinct from that of Vatican City State, is supported financially by a variety of sources, including investments, real estate income, and donations from Catholic individuals, dioceses, and institutions; these help fund the Roman Curia (Vatican bureaucracy), diplomatic missions, and media outlets. Moreover, an annual collection taken up in dioceses and direct donations go to a non-budgetary fund known as Peter's Pence, which is used directly by the Pope for charity, disaster relief and aid to churches in developing nations.{#cite_note-126}
{#cite_note-126}
